6.1.6 Discussion
The proposed methodology, which integrates geophysical and morphometric data,
successful allowed the semi?automated mapping of geological units in the central part of the
onshore Paraíba Basin. High correspondence between K and Th concentrations, derived from
airborne gamma?spectrometry and geochemical analyses, was noted elsewhere (e.g., IAEA,
2003; Teruiya et al., 2008). Indeed, these data were useful for the geological mapping of the
study area. The K and Th concentrations obtained by geophysical analysis were higher than
those derived from geochemical analysis, likely because of the spectral mixture among targets
resulting from the lower spatial resolution (90 m; IAEA, 2003) of the airborne survey data, as
opposed to the precise location of the geochemical data.
The first leaf node of the decision tree related to the discrimination between
Precambrian basement rocks and sedimentary units based on K concentration. This is
attributed to the sharp mineralogical contrast between these lithologies. Gneisses and
granodiorites are common rocks of the Precambrian basement in northeastern Brazil (e.g.,
Castro et al., 2007; Medeiros et al., 2011; Teruiya et al., 2008), including the study area of the
onshore Paraíba Basin (Brito Neves et al., 2001). The high K concentration of such acidic
rocks is widely known in the literature (e.g., Matolin, 1984). Specifically in the study area, the
high K concentration is mainly attributed to the mineralogical composition of the rocks,
which includes K?feldspars and minerals such as biotite and muscovite (Guimarães et al.,
2011). On the other hand, the sedimentary units exposed in the Paraíba Basin are dominated
53
by quartzose sandstones, in addition to the stable heavy minerals zircon, tourmaline,
staurolite, rutile, and kyanite (Rossetti et al., 2012), which do not present K in their crystalline
structure. The Barreiras Formation constitutes an exception since it contains a certain amount
of mudstones, but clays in these deposits are mainly represented by kaolinite (e.g., Ochoa,
2010), which also lacks K in its structure. Therefore, K concentration alone enabled the
prompt distinction of Precambrian basement rocks from sedimentary deposits.
The second leaf node of the decision tree indicated that the creation and extraction of
masks were effective in separating the Gramame Formation from the other sedimentary units,
despite the low representativeness of this unit in the study area as well as in other areas of the
northeastern coast of Brazil.
The third leaf node revealed the elevation and slope morphometric data used for
discrimination of recent alluvial deposits. The fact that this unit presents a combination of low
elevation and slope values was expected considering the topographic condition of modern
alluvial deposits associated with the main rivers that cut down into the sedimentary units of
the onshore Paraíba Basin. These rivers have formed broad floodplains that configure lower
and flatter terrains when compared to the other units. Elevation and slope are morphometric
characteristics widely used in geomorphological and geological mapping (Gallant and Wilson,
2000; Miliaresis, 2008).
The fourth leaf node indicated relief?dissection as the parameter for separating the
Barreiras Formation from younger sedimentary units. The higher relief?dissection index of
this unit is promptly related to the longer duration of its subaerial exposure. This is attested by
the unconformity in its upper portion, which encompasses an extensive time frame from the
middle/late Miocene to Early Pleistocene. In addition, the topography over this unit was
defined not only by erosion, but also by tectonic reactivation, as shown by an increasing
record of faults and folds that have affected these deposits since the Miocene (e.g., Balsamo et
al., 2013; Bezerra et al., 2011, 2014). In particular, areas in the map where the Barreiras
Formation is more prevalent coincide with locations where such faults and folds were
recorded in abundance at the outcrops (Rossetti et al., 2011b). Thus, dissection might have
been more prominent over the Barreiras Formation due to topographic gradients imposed by
extension and compression.
54
However, the relief?dissection index failed to distinguish between PB1 and PB2. This
is likely due to the geologically young nature of these deposits, with little time for erosion to
take place and allow them to be discriminated based on this characteristic. Despite the fact
that the dissection index was not helpful in discriminating between PB1 and PB2, the fifth
leaf node of the decision tree indicated that these units could be discriminated based on the Th
product. Although the composition of both units is similarly dominated by quartzose sandy
lithologies, PB1 is often indurated due to cementation by iron oxides and hydroxides, while
PB2 is constituted essentially of clean sands. The iron constituents in PB1 fill interstitial
porosity or precipitate along bed planes, as well as along fault and fracture planes (Balsamo et
al., 2013; Rossetti et al., 2011a). According to the latter authors, the majority of deposits in
PB1 is represented by seismites. The sedimentary processes of such deposits included
re?sedimentation due to fluidization and/or liquefaction caused by the impact of seismic
waves on unconsolidated or semi?consolidated sediments. In addition, aftershocks would
have caused strong brittle deformation, resulting in pervasive faulting and fracturing. Such
conditions would have favored the large?scale percolation of iron oxides and hydroxides by
fluid motion along the grain interstices, as well as fault and fracture planes. Presumably, the
iron oxides and hydroxides introduced in such ways increased the Th concentration in the
gamma?ray spectrometric products, as previously reported by others (e.g., Dickson and Scott,
1997; Wilford at al., 1997). This occurs because the Th is physically captured in traps at the
surface of the iron minerals (e.g., Reiller et al., 2002).
The difficulty in distinguishing PB1 from the Barreiras Formation based on Th
concentration is also attributed to iron oxides and hydroxides. Similarly to PB1, the Barreiras
Formation contains a significant amount of Th, which is particularly concentrated in its upper
portion. The top of the formation is characterized by an unconformity marked by a
ferruginous lateritic paleosol developed from the middle/late Miocene to Pleistocene
(Rossetti, 2004; Rossetti et al., 2013). Th may have also been trapped in the iron minerals
during the development of this paleosol. The influence of densely urbanized areas on Th
concentration as indicated by the gamma?ray spectrometric data led to a sixth leaf node in the
decision tree. In addition to Th, this last node was resolved with the vectorization of urbanized
areas using the ASTER image, which allowed the exclusion of urbanized areas originally
mapped as PB2.
55
6.1.7 Conclusion
A semi?automated procedure integrating airborne gamma?ray spectrometry and
morphometry derived from DEM?SRTM was successfully performed for the geological
mapping at 1:100,000 scale of the central onshore Paraíba Basin. Success is established by the
high accuracy coefficients obtained during validation using field data. Notably, such mapping
was effective in differentiating sedimentary units of Neogene and, in particular, Quaternary
ages with great precision, and such distinctions have posed major difficulties when mapping
is based solely on field data. This work confirms the expressive occurrence of Neogene and
Quaternary deposits in the central onshore Paraíba Basin, with a distribution encompassing an
area twice as large as the Barreiras Formation. The K concentration was essential to
distinguish the Precambrian basement rocks from the sedimentary units of the basin. The Th
product and/or morphometric data consisting of elevation, slope and relief?dissection
contributed to discriminate the Barreiras Formation and younger units. The conclusion based
on such results is that this methodology, after minor adaptations, can serve to expand the
geological mapping of Neogene and Quaternary sedimentary successions in other areas of the
Brazilian coast, while optimizing the time and resources required for this type of work.

Abstract
The evolution of continental passive margins has been a subject of discussion in the
scope of global tectonics. Within this context, the South American passive margin comprises
a number of basins with sedimentary records useful to approach the several stages of
evolution of this passive margin since the opening of the Atlantic Ocean. Among these basins,
the Paraíba Basin is exceptionally of high interest to this kind of study because it represents
the last bridge connecting the South American and African plates. Hence, this basin represents
a geological site of particular interest for discussing the tectono?sedimentary evolution of the
South American passive margin, in special during the post?rift stage. The present work
combine surface and subsurface data based on analyses of outcrops, deep stratigraphic
profiles, as well as airborne geophysical and remote sensing information, aiming to establish a
model for the tectono?sedimentary evolution of the onshore Paraíba Basin since the late
Cretaceous. Characteristics such as the lateral coexistence of Cretaceous and Cenozoic units
in sharp contact, great contrast in the thicknesses of the strata over short distances, as well as
the abundance of structural features recognized with basis on the integration of
morphostructural, magnetic and structural data, led to propose a succession of events linked to
tectonic subsidence and uplift as the main control of depositional and denudational processes
in this basin. Tectonics remained active long after the main rifting. This is indicated by brittle
and ductile deformation consisting of normal, reverse, and strike?slip faults in addition to
folds, which were pervasively recorded even in Neogene and Late Pleistocene strata. In
addition to sea level fluctuations, the tectonic events produced multiple reactivations of
pre?existing E?W, NE?SW and NW?SE trending deep?based shear zones. Therefore, the
Paraíba Basin presents a diverse set of evidence supporting that South America passive
57
margin was intensively affected by post?rift tectonic activity, which continued up to the Late
Pleistocene. Hence, the data presented herein are incompatible with many models of mostly
steady passive continental margins during the post?rifting.
Key?words: passive margin, post?rift, brittle and ductile deformation, neotectonics.
6.2.1 Introduction
The tectono?sedimentary evolution of passive margins has been an issue of increasing
interest for research in these last decades (e.g., Matos, 1992; Brown et al., 2000; Japsen et al.,
2006; Greenroyd et al., 2008; Antobreh et al., 2009; Pedoja et al., 2011; Basile et al., 2013).
The most significant advance reported about this theme has certainly been the knowledge that
passive margins might have a complex evolution in time and space. This is a reflex of activity
along transform faults and/or oceanic fracture zones, as some of them may have remained
unsteady through time (Greenroyd et al., 2008; Basile et al., 2013). A few recent publications
are in agreement with the model of a tectonically active South American passive margin
during the post?rift phase. For instance, Japsen et al. (2012) proposed that the evolution of
this margin incorporates post?rift subsidence and uplift, which might have extended even to
the end of the Quaternary. In addition, an increasing number of publications have proposed
tectonic reactivation as the main control influencing the depositional history and the
geomorphological evolution in northeastern Brazil, with tectonic evidence extending up to the
late Quaternary (e.g., Saadi and Torquato, 1992; Bezerra et al., 2005, 2008, 2011; Rossetti et
al., 2011a,b, 2012). These publications are in disagreement with pre?existing, and usually
more accepted, model of landscape evolution of coastal areas in northeastern Brazil as a result
of a succession of erosional phases by climatic changes subsequent to the separation of South
America and Africa (e.g., King, 1956; Mabesoone and Castro, 1976).
Additional and more systematic data aiming to fully characterize tectonic structures
and deformation styles in northeastern Brazil are still needed for advancing the discussion on
the conflicting climatic versus tectonic model to explain sediment deposition and landscape
evolution during the post?rift stage. The Paraíba Basin is a geological site exceptionally prone
to this kind of investigation, because it represents the last bridge connecting the South
American and African plates (Matos, 1992; Françolin et al., 1994; Oliveira and Gomes,
1996). Hence, this basin remained tectonically active longer than other areas of northeastern
Brazil. Thus, the Paraíba Basin is scientifically appropriate for investigating the post?rift
58
tectonics in northeastern Brazil, a study further favored by the following characteristics of this
basin: (i) a large amount of outcrops of exceptional high quality for the purpose of geological
investigation, including the presence of an abundance of tectonic structures; (ii) the reduced
vegetation cover that favors an efficient use of some remote sensing techniques, such as the
digital elevation model (DEM) derived from the Shuttle Radar Topography Mission (SRTM),
to investigate the surface expression of tectonic structures; (iii) the availability of a complete
magnetometric survey that might help to analyze the physical continuity of tectonic structures
in subsurface; and (iv) a considerable amount of boreholes that allows complete the
interpretation of tectonic structures in subsurface through correlation of stratigraphic units. A
recent publication combining similar surface and subsurface data was undertaken in
northeastern Brazil (Bezerra et al., 2014). However, that work focused on a large area of
northeastern Brazil, and the proposed neotectonic reactivation due to strike?slip deformation
proposed by those authors included only a few data from the Paraíba Basin.
The present work is focused on tectonic structures of the onshore Paraíba Basin in
order to provide a detailed characterization of their style, geometries and trends through the
integration of surface and subsurface data using outcrops, boreholes, remote sensing and
magnetometry. The goals consisted in further demonstrating the significance of tectonic
activity in this basin, reconstructing deformation phases through time, as well as establishing
a tectono?sedimentary model and analyzing its link to the evolution of the South American
passive margin during the post?rift phase.
6.2.2 Geological setting
The onshore Paraíba Basin encompasses an area of 5,073 km 2 located between the
Pernambuco shear zone, to the south, and the Mamanguape structural high, to the north, the
latter being a branch of the Patos shear zone (Fig. 6.2.1A,B). To the west, this basin is in
contact with the Borborema structural province (Kegel, 1955; Almeida, 1967; Brito Neves,
1984), which comprises an area of 450,000 km² consisting of Paleoproterozoic and
Neoproterozoic igneous and metamorphic rocks. Many fractures and faults associated with
major sigmoidal?shaped and mostly E?W, ENE?WSW and NE?SW?trending shear zones
formed during the Brasiliano cycle (~ 540 Ma) cross over this province (Almeida et al., 2000;
Brito Neves et al., 2000, 2001). The last major tectonic event in this province is related to the
opening of the southern Atlantic Ocean in the late Jurassic to early Cretaceous, a process that
gave rise to the establishment of several sedimentary basins along the eastern South American
59
plate (e.g., Rand and Mabesoone, 1982; Nürnberg and Müller, 1991; Matos, 1992), as well as
to a few onshore aborted rifts (Matos, 1992; Almeida et al., 2000).
In the early Cretaceous, there was a variation in tectonic style as the extensional stress
field from NW?SE to E?W (Matos, 1992). Extension continued after the Cretaceous,
affecting the area that corresponds to the Paraíba Basin (Brito Neves et al., 2004). The field
stresses were first concentrated along ancient E?W to ENE?WSW?trending shear zones of
the Proterozoic basement (Fig. 6.2.1). However, other extensional trends seem to have
developed during the Cenozoic (e.g., Bezerra and Vita?Finzi, 2000; Bezerra et al., 2001,
2008, 2014; Barreto et al., 2002).

The complex tectonic history of the Paraíba Basin is evidenced by the superposition of
many faults that cross Cretaceous, Neogene and Quaternary units (e.g., Bezerra et al., 2008).
In particular, N?S?extensional and E?W?compressional stress fields prevailed over this
region since the Miocene (Ferreira et al., 2008; Nogueira et al., 2010; Reis et al., 2013). Faults
derived from normal and strike?slip motion produced a series of horst and graben structures
along the coastal zone (Bezerra and Vita?Finzi, 2000; Bezerra et al., 2001, 2008; Furrier et
al., 2006; Nogueira et al., 2010; Andrades Filho and Rossetti, 2012a). The Cariatá trough is an
example of a graben formed by reactivation of existing faults during the Quaternary, with a
first extensional deformation forming normal faults before the Late Pleistocene, and a second
event giving rise to strike?slip faults during the Late Pleistocene (Brito Neves et al., 2004;
Bezerra et al., 2008). A large amount of seismogenic data from several areas of northeastern
Brazil document earthquakes of moderate to high magnitudes distributed along major fault
zones, such as the Samambaia Fault (e.g., Ferreira et al., 1998)., and this attest that tectonic
reactivation is still going on at the present (Ferreira et al., 2008; Bezerra et al., 2011).
The sedimentary fill (Fig. 6.2.1C) of the Paraíba Basin began in the
Coniacian?Santonian, after the opening of the Atlantic Ocean (Matos, 1992). During this
time, medium? to coarse?grained sandstones and conglomerates of the Beberibe Formation
formed in fluvial and lacustrine environments (Beurlen, 1967). The Itamaracá Formation
overlying this unit includes carbonates mixed with calciferous sandstones and shales which
were formed in estuarine and lagoon to shelf environments during the
Campaniana?Maastrichtian age (Barbosa et al., 2003). A generalized transgression is
recorded in this basin by carbonate rocks of the Gramame Formation, which record deposition
in shallow shelf environment during the Maastrichtian (Barbosa et al., 2003). A less
expressive transgression is recorded in the Paleogene by the carbonate rocks of the Maria
Farinha Formation (Mabesoone, 1994). This unit was not distinguished from the Gramame
Formation in the present work due to its restrict geographic distribution.
Sediment accumulation continued in the Paraíba Basin in the Miocene, giving rise to a
siliciclastic unit composed by sandstone, mudstone and, to a lesser extension, conglomerate.
These are recorded by the Barreiras Formation. which is a unit first regarded as entirely
continental in origin (Araújo et al., 2006; Morais et al., 2006), but which has been
reinterpreted as encompassing mostly transitional marine, mainly estuarine, environments
(e.g., Rossetti and Góes, 2009; Rossetti et al., 2013). These deposits are well represented in
61
the central east of Paraíba Basin (Fig. 6.2.2). However, the geographically most expressive
unit of this basin in surface consists of the Post?Barreiras sediments. These were subdivided
into two subunits, informally designated as PB1 and PB2 (Rossetti et al., 2011b). PB1 was
formed in the Late Pleistocene and consists mostly of sandstones and conglomerates, with
subordinate mudstone. A great part of PB1 is massive and deformed deposits attributed to
seismites (Rossetti et al., 2011a). PB2 corresponds to well to poorly sorted sands deposited
during the Holocene mostly by aeolian processes (Rossetti et al., 2011b).

6.2.3 Material and methods
The materials used in this work derived from boreholes, outcrops, mainly coastal cliffs
and road cuts, as well as, remote sensing imagery and airborne geophysical magnetometric data.
A total of 140 boreholes were acquired from the collection of the Geological Survey of
Brazil (CPRM) and geocoded in Geographic Information System (GIS) to compose the basis
for stratigraphic correlations. These were combined with information derived from
lithostratigraphic profiles acquired at the outcrops, which discrimination of the individual
geological units. The stratigraphic correlation was based on five latitudinal and three
longitudinal transects, which were established according to location and areas of interest for
this research. The topographic positions of individual boreholes and litostratigraphic profiles
were established with basis on data achieved from the DEM?SRTM accessed at
http://srtm.csi.cgiar.org. The SRTM?3” version was used in this work, which results from
new interpolation algorithms and auxiliary DEM (Reuter et al., 2007), produced as 3
arc?seconds grid (i.e., approximate resolution of 90 m). The following data relative to the
geological units were observed on the geological sections: i) horizontal distribution; ii)
thickness; iii) relative vertical positioning; and iv) expression in surface.
The analysis of tectonic structures in the outcrops included descriptions of the overall
geometry deformation types, as well as attitude of faults (i.e., strike and dip), folds (i.e., fold
axes), and beddings (i.e., dip angle and dip azimuth). The documentation of tectonic
structures was complemented by photographies taken in the field and by helicopter. The
structural data were processed using the Stereonet 8.8.6 software package (Allmendinger et
al., 2013). Stereograms were generated using measurements of fault and beddings planes in
equal?area projection, including contour plots with 1% area contouring. The sedimentary
units containing the tectonic structures were described in the field. The chronology of the
Quaternary strata is based on optically stimulated luminescence analysis documented in
Rossetti et al. (2011b).
The morphostructural lineaments were extracted by visual interpretation of
DEM?SRTM data obtained from the TOPODATA geomorphometic database (Valeriano and
Rossetti, 2012), accessed at http://www.dpi.inpe.br/topodata. These data consist of grid values
measuring 1 arc?second (i.e, approximately 30 m resolution), refined from the SRTM?3"
(i.e., 90 m resolution) and include elevation data, aspect and horizontal curvature. Straight
64
lineaments were vectorized from positive and negative reliefs recognized in images derived
from the morphometric variables. In addition, the DEM enhanced by shading schemes and
palettes were also used the morphostructural lineaments. These morphometric products and
DEM are available. The effectiveness of this methodology for mapping morphostructural
lineaments was previously shown by Andrades Filho and Rossetti (2012b). Morphostructural
compartments were discriminated with basis on the distribution of lineament patterns. The
mapping of morphostructural features was complemented by the analysis of an optical image
acquired by the Advanced Spaceborne Thermal Emission and Reflection Radiometer
(ASTER), at the spatial resolution of 15 m (Yamaguchi et al., 1999), obtained on June 11, 2009.
The continuity of some morphostructural lineaments in subsurface was determined by
the analysis of magnetometric geophysical data. The magnetic data used in this study were
collected by the Airborne Geophysical Survey Project (LASA and Prospectors, 2008)
commissioned by the Geological Survey of Brazil (CPRM) in March?April of 2008. This
project surveyed high resolution aeromagnetic profiles, with flight lines spaced 500 m and
control lines spaced 5,000 m, oriented in the N?S and E?W directions, respectively. The
flying height was set at 100 meters above the ground. Aircraft equipped with magnetometer
positioned by Global Positioning System (GPS) observation satellite with a precision of 1 m
system were employed. The cesium vapor magnetometer sensor was mounted on the tail of
the aircraft (type stinger). Measurements were taken every 0.1 seconds, which is equivalent,
depending on the average speed of the aircraft, to a measurement every 7.7 meters (LASA and
Prospectors, 2008). The magnetic data were submitted to the micro?levelling routines aiming
for the extraction of high?frequency signals deriving from levelling process problems. The
contribution of the International Geomagnetic Reference Field (IGRF) was subtracted from
the micro?levelled data. Then the data were interpolated into a grid of 125 x 125 m. In
addition to the original magnetic data (nT), the processed product, denominated first vertical
derivative of the magnetic field (nT/m), was also used. This processing was applied to the
data in the wavenumber domain after the application of the Fast Fourier Transform (FFT).
Narrow and elongated magnetic anomalies are commonly interpreted according to three main
types of geological correlations: i) tectonic structures such fault or shear zone; ii) contact
between two geological units; and iii) intrusion of magnetic bodies of type dike. As the first
vertical derivative enhances very well those types of feature, it was used to visual
interpretation of the magnetic lineaments.
65
Rose diagrams and Kernel density maps were generated from morphostructural
lineaments derived from the analysis of both remote sensing and magnetometric data in order
to establish the main trends of these structures. The rose diagrams were generated at intervals
of 10° according to the absolute frequency of lineaments corresponding to the exposed
geological units and the morphostructural compartments. The morphostructural and magnetic
lineaments were also comparatively analyzed.
6.2.4 Results
Surface and subsurface data integration enabled obtaining fundamental information for
tectono?sedimentary analyzes performed using stratigraphic correlation, characterization of
morphostructural and magnetic lineaments and deformation structures in outcrops.
6.2.4.1 Stratigraphic correlation
The stratigraphic correlation integrating the borehole and lithostratigraphic profiles
throughout the study area (Figs. 6.2.3 and 6.2.4) enabled the discrimination of four geological
units: Precambrian basement, Beberibe Formation, Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations, and,
Barreiras Formation/Post?Barreiras sediments. The geological map allowed to include in the
cross sections modern alluvial sediments of main rivers.
Sections A to D (Figs. 6.2.4A?D), G and H (Figs. 6.2.4G,H) record only the
sedimentary units of the basin, whereas sections E (Fig. 6.2.4E) and F (Fig. 6.2.4F) depict
these units in sharp lateral contact with Precambrian basement rocks to the west. The analysis
of the studied transects revealed that the Beberibe Formation is generally the most expressive
unit in subsurface, reaching up to 170 m in thickness in section E (Fig. 6.2.4E). However, this
unit was not documented in any of the studied outcrops. The Beberibe Formation is sharply
overlain by the carbonates of the Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations. These deposits were
also recorded in all sections, but they are particularly well represented in the W?E trending
sections (i.e., C to F), where they become thicker to the east reaching a maximum of 100 m in
section E (Fig. 6.2.4E). The Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations were also recorded in
surface, being well exposed along several discontinuous outcrops located along or near the
modern coastline. The Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations constitute a good stratigraphic
marker for distinguishing the underlying Beberibe Formation from the overlying
66
Barreiras/Post?Barreiras deposits. These are also distributed along all analyzed sections, but
with greater thicknesses (i.e., ~100 m) being recorded in sections F and H (Figs. 6.2.4F,H).
Figure 6.2.3 ? A) Location of cross?sections generated from borehole and field data, over
DEM?SRTM; B) Area zoomed from A with main rivers in eastern portion.
A remarkable observation derived from the analysis of all studied transects is the great
offsets of the geological units that may reach up to several tens or even a few hundred meters
within short distances. Such characteristic could not be related only to erosional relief, but it
requires an interpretation of bed displacement due to the presence of numerous faults, as
suggested in Fig. 6.2.4. It is noteworthy that many faults depicted in this figure have
correspondence with morphostructural lineaments extracted with basis on remote sensing and
magnetometric data (see descriptions of these data in sections 6.2.4.2 and 6.2.4.3).
Additionally, many faulted areas interpreted in these sections coincide with outcrops
dominated by an abundance of faults. The interpretation of folded strata depicted in the
geological sections derives from the fact that many field exposures display pervasive folds
associated with faults (see descriptions of these structures in section 6.2.4.4).
67

(see Fig. 6.2.3 for the transects location).
Aspects of the geological sections that are useful to show the tectonic control in the
study area will be highlighted herein after. For instance, the Precambrian rocks extend over 47
and 30 km in transects E and F, respectively, but they disappear suddenly eastward in both
68
sections before the Gramame River (Fig. 6.2.4E,F). In section E, the contact of these rocks
with the sedimentary units, mainly the Beberibe Formation, is marked by an offset > 200 m,
implying the presence of a normal fault dipping roughly to the east. It is interesting to note
that this area has equivalence with the Embratel dome, which corresponds to a prominent
convex?up structure with expression also in surface (Fig. 6.2.5A,B). Also noteworthy is that
the Cretaceous units are restricted to the areas located to the east of this feature, which is in
turn overlain only by the Barreiras/Post?Barreiras deposits. In section F, the Precambrian
rocks display several offsets up to 120 m. These offsets produced a graben where the Paraíba
River became established. The faults to the east created space to accommodate a thicker
succession of deposits corresponding to the Barreiras/Post?Barreiras units, and also placed
these strata in lateral contact with the Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations.
The sedimentary units also display several offsets that can only be justified by the
presence of faults and even folds. These structures, in particular faults, can be inferred in all
sections, but they are better represented in sections E to H (Figs. 6.2.4E to H). Hence, in
section E the Beberibe Formation displays several offsets, the greatest one being more than
100 m. The subsided blocks resulting from these displacements created space to accommodate
the Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations, which is up to 80 m thick over this area where a
graben feature is inferred, while westward it changes abruptly to only a few meters and then
disappears at the Taperubus River. It is interesting to notice that the Barreiras/Post?Barreiras
deposits are also thicker, i.e., >100 m over the lowest subsided block, average only 50 m to
the west of the main offset of the Beberibe Formation. This implies that these deposits were
also faulted, which is confirmed by many drainage anomalies suggestive of faults, some with
lateral displacements typical of transcurrence (Fig. 6.2.5C,D).
Sections F to H are interesting because it shows several displacements of the
sedimentary units, which produced a geometry of grabens and horsts. In F (Fig. 6.2.4F), the
sedimentary units are essentially horizontal to the west of the Gramame River, which are in
great contrast with the series of offsets to the east of this river. However, it is remarkable that
the Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations are slightly thicker over this area, constituting a
series of steps that progressively dip eastward. Nevertheless, as opposed to section E, these
displaced deposits are positioned at higher elevation (i.e., 50 to 15 m) relative to the
horizontal strata to the west, which locates at<10 m of altitude. Due to this characteristic,
added to the fact that this area contains many outcrops with folds, the displacements of the
69
sedimentary units in the eastward part of section F are better accommodated with basis on a
geometry of faults associated with folds. It is interesting to notice that the
Barreiras/Post?Barreiras deposits are thinner over this area relatively to their occurrences to
the west, suggesting that this could have constituted a high since the deposition of these units.
It is also remarkable that the Gramame River occurs right at the contact between the area with
horizontal strata and the area with faulted/folded strata, in a place where faults are also
inferred to accommodate an offset of almost 50 m of the sedimentary units.

6.2.4.2 Morphostructural lineaments
Characteristics of the morphostructural lineaments, such as density and spatial
distribution, led to the recognition of four compartments, designated C1 to C4, with
compartments C1 to C3 corresponding to the sedimentary units of the Paraíba Basin (Fig.
6.2.2), and C4 corresponding to the Precambrian basement rocks (Fig. 6.2.6A?C). C1, which
occurs mostly on PB2 (Fig. 6.2.2) located to the north of the study area, is characterized by
the lowest density of lineaments. Most of these are lineaments extracted from negative reliefs,
as this area is chiefly flat?lying. C2 and C3 correspond to areas with prevalence of the
Barreiras Formation and PB1. However, C2, located in the center of the study area, shows
moderate lineament density, while C3, located in the extreme eastern part of the study area,
displays a C4, which corresponds to the area with dominance of Precambrian basement rocks
to the west, is characterized by the prevalence of moderate and high lineament density values.

6.2.4.3 Magnetic lineaments
The magnetic lineaments are well distributed throughout the study area (Fig
6.2.6D?F). Compartments C1 to C3 generally have equivalent distribution of low and
moderate density, with a slight increased concentration of the latter to the west, close to the
boundary with C4. There is only one area with high magnetic lineament density on the area
corresponding to sedimentary units, which coincides with the Embratel dome (Fig. 6.2.5A,B).
The lineament density increases slightly on compartment C4, which has dominantly moderate
values, with subordinate low values. In addition, lineaments in this compartment are more are
longer than in the sedimentary units.
The magnetic lineaments display consistent patterns over compartments C1 to C3,
with a main NE?SW trend and a subordinate NW?SE trend. In addition, C2 and C3 have also
a well?defined E?W trend, although this constitutes a subordinate mode. In the Precambrian
basement rocks, the magnetic lineaments trend mainly in the ENE?WSW, WNW?ESE and
E?W directions.
Considering the total amount of lineaments, the Precambrian basement rocks recorded
a considerable higher value (i.e., 120) than the sedimentary units together (i.e., 96). Among
the latter, the Barreiras Formation and PB1 had more lineaments, varying from 215 to 196,
respectively, while PB2 displayed only 72 lineaments.
A comparison between the morphostructural and magnetic lineaments led to the
conclusion that they are not always correlated. In general, the best coincidence in these data is
found in association with the Precambrian basement rocks. Over the areas corresponding to
the sedimentary basin, the magnetic lineaments are less defined, and many of them do not
74
match exactly with the morphostructural lineaments. However, there are places where the
magnetic data displays good correspondence with morphostructural lineaments. For instance,
the Paraíba River has many NE?SW trending morphostructural lineaments that are in perfect
agreement with trends derived from magnetic data (Fig. 6.2.8A,B). A long segment of this
river occurs over a well?defined magnetic anomaly in the center of the Cariatá Graben
previously defined by Bezerra et al. (2008) (Fig. 6.2.8C,D). In addition, the magnetic and
morphostructural lineaments have good match along the upper course of Mamuaba and high
block of the basement to the west (Fig. 6.2.8E,F). The Goiana River valley displays an
anomalous enlargement in the coastal zone, with a rectangular branch displaying
morphostructural lineaments with correspondence in the magnetic data (Fig. 6.2.8G,H).

6.2.5 Discussion
6.2.5.1 Distribution and relation of the structures to tectonic reactivation
The data presented here attests that the Paraíba Basin was extensively affected by
tectonic activity. The pervasive structures recorded in the Barreiras Formation and PB1 unit,
including an abundance of normal, reverse and strike?slip faults, as well as joints and folds,
assure that this area of eastern South American passive margin experienced significant
tectonism during the late stages of its post?rift history. The generally comparable
morphostructural lineaments recorded in compartments C2 and C3, relative to the lineaments
over the Precambrian basement rocks, led to the conclusion that the events that affected the
Barreiras Formation and PB1 unit are attributed to reactivation of pre?existing structures. It
follows that the majority of the lineaments of the study area can be related to reactivations of
pre?existing shear zones and other large linear structures that extend over the Precambrian
basement. Hence, E?W, NE?SW and NW?SE trending structures were reactivated through
87
time, extending their influence into the Paraíba Basin. However, the presence of structures
displaying strikes trending N?S only in the Barreiras Formation and PB1 unit, while they
have no significant expression neither over areas dominated by Precambrian basement rocks
nor over the areas dominated by the PB2 unit might be an indication for a tectonic event that
was restricted to a certain period of the geological time of the Neogene and/or Late
Pleistocene.
The fact that the Precambrian basement presents a much higher density of
morphostructural lineaments in relation to the sedimentary units is probably due to the
superposition of different deformation events by which these rocks have been affected since
the Precambrian period. The equivalent trends and density of morphostructural lineaments
over compartments C2 and C3, which are dominated by the Barreiras Formation and PB1
unit, might be a suggestion of tectonic reactivation mainly after deposition of the latter. This
is because if a significant tectonism had affected the Barreiras Formation before deposition of
PB1 unit, then the first would have been imprinted by a higher amount of lineaments. It is
also interesting to note that the lower amount of lineaments in the PB2 unit is compatible with
its younger age relative to PB1 unit.
Because the magnetic lineaments are also more expressive over the Precambrian
basement rocks, it can be concluded that they record pre?existing, deep?based shear zones.
Although not entirely correlated with the morphostructural lineaments, the ENE?WSW,
WNW?ESE and E?W dominating modes of these features do not differ much from the trend
recorded by morphostructural lineaments of the Precambrian basement, which further support
their interrelationship. The presence of many magnetic lineaments in the area with
sedimentary units that do not match well with morphostructural lineaments was reported
elsewhere (e.g., Jacques et al., 2014), and can be tentatively related to: (i) many deep
structures that do not affect the sedimentary units; and/or (ii) deep structures that may have
generated different deformation styles on the sedimentary cover, which could have attenuated
their effect in shallow depths through formation of smaller structures that are not necessarily
positioned in the same location at the surface.
6.2.5.2 Deformation style and stress field
The deformation structures documented in the study area are complex, revealing
extensional and compressional stresses, in addition to strike?slip motion, as also recorded in
88
other areas of northeastern Brazil (e.g., Ferreira et al., 1998, Bezerra et al., 2011, 2014; Reis et
al., 2013). The complex style of deformation is also suggested by the frequent presence of
faults forming conjugate systems. Although this issue is still open for debate, faults in these
systems might suggest the superposition of events. Previous publications have already
suggested multi?phase faulting affecting Neogene and Quaternary units in northeastern Brazil
with basis on structural and chronological evidence (e.g., Japsen et al., 2012; Gurgel et al.,
2013; Bezerra et al., 2014).
The prevalence of normal faults with strikes trending mainly to E?W in the
compartments C2 and C3 indicates that the Barreiras Formation and the PB1 unit were
undergone to stronger N?S extension. The occurrence of secondary trends to NE?SW and
NW?SE also attests that these units were affected by subordinate NW?SE and NE?SW
extensional phases. As mentioned above, these deformational phases might have been resulted
from reactivation of pre?existing deep?based shear zones. Furthermore, the normal faults
with strikes trending N?S probably record an independent event of E?W extension that seems
to be unrelated to pre?existing faults.
The pervasive occurrence of reverse faults attests that, in addition to extension,
compressional deformation contributed to displace the sedimentary units, particularly the
Barreiras Formation and the PB1 unit. Because these faults are closely associated with the
normal faults, and they also show similar strike trends, it can be concluded that extension was
interacting with compression. Hence, the Barreiras Formation and the PB1 unit was
undergone to a main N?S compressional phase, having subordinate compression oriented in
the NW?SE and NE?SW directions.
The presence of compressional deformation in the study area is further evidenced by
the large occurrence of broad synclines and anticlines. The majority of the folds displaying
E?W trending axes is compatible with a main N?S compressional deformation, as also
suggested by the trends of the reverse faults; only locally E?W compression was reported.
These data are not in agreement with focal mechanism of deformation previously proposed
for northeastern Brazil, which has considered E?W compression as the most significant
taking into account only structural data derived from Precambrian basement rocks (e.g.,
Ferreira et al., 1998, Bezerra et al., 2011; Reis et al., 2013). Considering these conflicting
interpretations, it could be hypothesized that the compressional deformation styles in the
Paraíba Basin differs from other areas in northeastern Brazil. Alternatively, it could be also
89
proposed that the sedimentary units of Neogene and Late Pleistocene age were undergone to
an independent phase of compressive deformation that has no correlation with deep?based
structures.
The presence of strike?slip faults in the study area is entirely consistent with a
proposed focal mechanism of deformation that combines extension and compression. This is
because strike–slip faults result from tectonic deformation styles characterized by lateral
displacements, which in cross?section present reverse or normal motion depending if the fault
geometry is transpressional or transtensional (e.g. Christie?Blick and Biddle, 1985; Sylvester,
1988). The dominant E?W and secondary WNW?ESE trending strikes of the strike?slip
faults in the study area are compatible with N?S and secondarily NNE?SSW extensional
deformation. In addition, the association of these features with normal and reverse faults, as
well as folds, is quite consistent with the conclusion that the combination of extensional and
compressional deformation in the study area can be explained within the context of a
transpressional/transtensional tectonic regime.
6.2.5.3 Tectono?sedimentary evolution
The analysis integrating the geological sections interpreted with basis on the
correlation of boreholes and lithostratigraphic profiles, the morphostructural and magnetic
lineaments, and the characterization of tectonic structures at the outcrop scale, altogether
allowed the reconstruction of the following tectono?sedimentary history for the Paraîba Basin
(Fig. 6.2.19).
The initial deposition in the late Cretaceous supports the proposal that this basin was
the last one to be formed along the eastern Brazilian margin (Matos, 1992, 1999). Indeed, a
borehole in the southern part of the Paraíba Basin reached the Precambrian basement at 400 m
depth without crossing any deposition prior to the Turonian (Barbosa et al., 2007). Until the
Coniacian, the area corresponding to this basin constituted a high of the Precambrian
basement (Fig. 6.2.19A, B). Thus, this basin followed a distinct evolution when compared to
the other basins of the northeastern passive margin of Brazil, which had their origin in the
early Cretaceous (Szatmari et al., 1987; Lima Filho, 1998).
In the Coniacian to Campanian, Precambrian basement rocks were displaced by
several normal faults with offsets of at least 200 m and having main dips to the east, a process
90
that would have created space for the establishment of the Paraíba Basin between the Patos
Shear Zone to the north and the Pernambuco High to the south (Fig. 6.2.1). The Beberibe
Formation initiated its deposition in the Coniacian, and culminated with a thick sedimentary
succession that were accommodated over the subsiding blocks (Fig. 6.2.19C). The maximum
westward distribution of this unit, i.e., around 20 km from the modern coastline (Fig.
6.2.19D), indicates the part of the basin that underwent to subsidence during this time. The
focal deformation mechanism linked to this tectonic event is related to E?W extension
(Matos, 1992).
Subsidence would have increased erosion in highland areas of the Precambrian
basement, with subsequent transportation of high volumes of sediments that were trapped in
the subsiding blocks, generating the Beberibe Formation. A main sediment source from the
Precambrian basement rocks for this unit was confirmed by heavy mineral analysis (Ochoa,
2010; Rossetti et al., 2012). The deposits of the Beberibe Formation continued being formed
mainly in continental environments until the Campanian (Barbosa et al., 2007).
91
Figure 6.2.19 – Tectono?sedimentary evolution stages in the central onshore Paraíba Basin.
92
In the Maastrichtian to Paleogene there was a major change in the basin depositional
processes, as a marine transgression deposited a thick succession of carbonates overlying the
Beberibe Formation (Fig. 6.2.19E). Paleontological studies suggest that the carbonate
deposition occurred mostly in shallow marine environments with depths <100 to 150 m
(Muniz, 1993). This transgression could be a response of global sea level, which was still at a
highstand during most of the Maastrichtian in consequence of the Cenomanian transgressive
trend (e.g., Haq et al., 1987; Haq and Al?Qahtani, 2005). However, sea level alone could not
explain the large variations in the thickness of the Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations over
short distances, as recorded by the analysis of the stratigraphic sections presented here. This
characteristic, added to the fact that these deposits are consistently much thicker within
graben geometries, leads to propose that deposition was triggered by tectonic reactivation,
with sedimentation taking place contemporaneous to this event. Thus, reactivation of
deep?based faults occurred after deposition of the Beberibe Formation, which promoted great
displacements of these deposits, and generated new space to accommodate the overlying
carbonate succession. In these subsiding areas, the overall tendency of sea level highstand
may have been accentuated, increasing the transgressive nature and promoting the deposition
of a thick carbonate deposits. On the other hand, highland areas of the basement and also
those within the basin representative of rising tectonic blocks, such as the area between the
Embratel dome and the Abiaí River shown in section E (Fig. 6.2.4E) and the Conde?Alhandra
High shown in section H (Fig. 6.2.4H), remained protected from the effect of this
transgression, and consequently do not display these overlying strata or show only a thin
veneer of them. Subsequent erosion over these highlands may have also further contributed to
partially erode or completely vanish any eventual transgressive deposits that might have
reached these areas. The geographic distribution of the Gamamme/Maria Farinha Formations
inland is equivalent to the distribution of the Beberibe Formation (compare Figs 6.2.19D and
F), which confirms their confinement to the area under effect of rifting. The uppermost
portion of carbonate succession, represented by the Maria Farinha Formation may record an
independent transgression in the Paleogene, which resulted in shallow marine deposition even
after the early Eocene (Beurlen, 1967). The carbonate deposition appears to have ended after
that time, when there was a widespread development of an unconformity with lateritic
paleosols (Fig. 6.2.19G, H), a feature also recognized throughout many other basins of
northeastern and northern Brazil(e.g., Rossetti, 2004; Rossetti et al., 2013).
93
After the Eocene, there is no record of sedimentation in the Paraíba Basin up to the
Miocene. We interpret that this period of non?sedimentation may be linked to a tectonic
stability, which was also associated to a phase of sea level lowering (Fig. 6.2.19G). The Barreiras
Formation records a period of renewed deposition in the Paraíba Basin (Fig. 6.2.19I, J). This
unit, widespread over many other areas of northeastern and northern Brazil, has been related
to the combined effect of high sea level in the early to middle Miocene and tectonic
subsidence (Rossetti et al., 2013). As reported for the Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations,
the Barreiras Formation becomes also thicker, at least locally, when overlying graben
geometries, as reported for instance in section E (see the graben to the right of the Garaú
River in Fig. 6.2.4E) and F (see the graben associated with the Gramame River in Fig.
6.2.4F). These evidences allow hypothesize that the return to sediment deposition during the
Miocene might have been triggered by the creation of new accommodation space promoted
by fault reactivation. This process was most likely combined with the global rise in sea level
that are well recorded in many other Miocene strata of South America (Mörner, 1991, 2009;
Frassineti and Covacevich, 1999; Scasso and Castro, 1999; Marengo, 2006; Cuitiño and
Scasso, 2010; Cuitiño et al., 2012) and also worldwide (e.g., Haq et al., 1987; Miller et al.,
2005).
However, such Miocene transgression was not as extensive as the
Cenomanian?Maastrichtian one. Indeed, it has been proposed that the Miocene sea level rise
along the Brazilian coast was in the order of only 60 m above the present (Rossetti et al.,
2013), while the Cretaceous rise would have reached circa 180 m above the present,
according to estimates of the global sea level chart (Haq et al., 1987). Therefore, sea level rise
alone could not explain the fact that the Barreiras Formation is geographically more
widespread than the Cretaceous strata inland in the Paraíba Basin (Fig. 6.2.19J). The presence
of the Barreiras Formation circa 40 km westward near the border of the Paraíba Basin leads to
propose that tectonic subsidence amplified the Paraíba Basin to the west, although the
resulting fault offsets may have been less pronounced than during the Cretaceous.
Furthermore, mineralogical provenance data support this model, indicating that the Barreiras
Formation sediments source is in the adjacent crystalline basement rocks, and not in the
pre?existing sedimentary units (Ochoa et al., 2013).
A key point is the foregoing evolutionary model proposed above is that
sin?sedimentary deformation structures were not observed in the Barreiras Formation, despite
94
the abundant of deformation structures. This leads to propose that there was a period of
tectonic reactivation prior to deposition of this unit, which may have been at least locally
contemporaneous to sediment deposition. However, most of the Barreiras Formation exposed
along the Paraíba Basin was not affected by a contemporaneous seismicity. Hence, the
numerous extensional and compressional deformation structures described in these deposits
were developed sometime after they reached a consolidated state, which happened possibly
much later in the Late Pleistocene, as further discussed hereinafter.
Between the middle Miocene and the Late Pleistocene, the Paraíba Basin experienced
a prolonged period of tectonic stability. This is recorded by another unconformity marked by
lateritic paleosol. Dating of supergenic goethites from this paleosol revealed its development
extending from a few million years before the middle Miocene to the Early/Middle
Pleistocene (Rossetti et al., 2012, 2013). Thus, one can assume this as the period of tectonic
quiescence in the Paraíba Basin. However, a drastic change took place in the Late Pleistocene,
when this basin was affected by significant tectonism of extensional and compressional focal
deformation. We interpret that this event occurred simultaneously to the deposition of the PB1
unit. This is proposed with basis on the fact that this unit displays an abundance of structures
suggestive of deposition under an unconsolidated and/or semi?consolidated state. These
include massive sandstones with isolated sand fragments and breccias, undulatory strata, sand
dykes and diapirs, sinks and bowls, pebbly pockets, plunged sediment mixtures, fitted sand
masses, cone?shaped cracks, fault grading and sedimentary enclaves, which were previously
described and related to seismites by Rossetti et al. (2011a). The presence of strike?slip faults
overlain by the PB1 unit containing soft sediment deformation that grades upward into
non?deformed beds, as illustrated in Fig. 6.2.14, is a further evidence in support of this
deposition simultaneously to seismic activity.
The good correspondence of the tectonic structures described in the PB1 unit and
Barreiras Formation, including equivalent values of morphostructural and magnetic
lineaments, may be taken to suggest that there was a period of intense tectonic activity in the
Late Pleistocene that affected both units. Reactivation of pre?existing structures would have
produced space to accommodate the new sedimentation corresponding to the PB1 unit, which
was formed contemporaneously to deformation. The numerous tectonic structures of the
underlying Barreiras Formation would have formed also during this phase. The most
interesting is that deformation included extensional and compressional focal mechanisms. The
95
latter intensively folded the Barreiras Formation and also the PB1 unit. It follows that the
most likely is to conceive a focal mechanism of deformation during and probably also
following deposition of PB1 unit. Such event might have been triggered by extension and
compression associated with transtensive and transpressive zones of deformation linked with
lateral displacements along strike?slip faults. It is interesting to note that uplift has been
suggested in coastal areas of northeastern Brazil (Japsen et al., 2012), as well as many others
worldwide, including passive margins (e.g., Pedoja et al., 2011), on Quaternary.
If the folds interpreted for the Cretaceous units with basis on correlation of the
stratigraphic sections were formed during this time or correspond to a previous compressional
phase is an issue that remains to be investigated. The occurrence of thicker strata of the
Gramame/Maria Farinha Formations in higher position with respect to thinner strata of these
units in adjacent areas may be an evidence of basin inversion. This is because the thicker
deposits were probably formed in a graben that was uplifted in a following stage. The time of
this uplifting is uncertain and it may be associated either with the Late Pleistocene
compression or a previous deformation phase. Another issue that remains open for discussion
is if the PB2 unit was also affected by tectonic activity. The morphostructural analysis
revealed several lineaments in the areas dominated by this unit, although of low density.
However, the analysis of outcrops did not reveal tectonic structures in these strata.
6.2.5.4 Deformation mechanism
As presented in the foregoing discussion, this integrated approach provided data to
assure that the tectono?sedimentary evolution of the onshore Paraíba Basin is chiefly linked
to the reactivation of deep?based shear zones of the Precambrian basement. In addition to the
Patos and Pernambuco shear zones, which define the northern and southern basin margins,
respectively, other large scale shear zones that cut through this basin are the Congo,
Camutanga and Itambé (Fig. 6.2.1B). All these shear zones are marked by expressive
magnetic lineaments. Within the basin, they also have good correspondence with
morphostructural lineaments that controlled the establishment of main river channels (Fig.
6.2.8). Hence, the Congo shear zone served as the site where the Paraíba River became
established. Similarly, the Camutanga and Itambé shear zones constitute pathways for the
later development of the Mamuaba and Goiana Rivers. This good correspondence of
deep?based structures with modern river systems cannot be coincidental, but they are
96
interpreted as the expression of the first on the present surface. The imprint of pre?existing
tectonic structures on a modern landscape covered by sedimentary deposits of Neogene and
Late Quaternary is taken as evidence that these features were reactivated in a relatively recent
geological time.
The shear zones that bound or cut through the Paraíba Basin correspond to major
features that characterize the Borborema Province and which are interpreted as E?W trending
dextral strike?slip fault zones that merge eastward into sinistral strike?slip faults (Neves et
al., 2000; Weinberg et al., 2004; Viegas, 2013). Such features, in particular the Patos and
Pernambuco shear zones, continue offshore into fracture zones of the southern Atlantic
Ocean, and were developed under the kinematic influence of these oceanic features (Matos,
2000). It follows that the tectonic reactivations recorded in the onshore Paraíba Basin may be
consequently linkage to post?rift motion along these oceanic fracture zones.
The dynamic evolution of oceanic fracture zones along the South American passive
margin remains to be investigated in more detail. However, it became well known the, as
opposed to the commonly accepted model of orthogonal rifting, this margin evolved from
oblique rifts (e.g., Greenroyd et al., 2008). These are rifts in which the continent?ocean
transition zone is not normal to the direction of seafloor spreading and to the trend of oceanic
fracture zones (e.g, Autin et al., 2010; Daoud et al., 2011; Umhoefer et al., 2011). A key
feature of passive margins associated with oblique rifts is the highly variable tectonic
deformation in terms of both style and timing, which will change according to the proximity
to a transform fault and/or fracture zone. The result is a polyphased evolution in space and
time, which might include even many post?rift tectonism (e.g., Faccenna et al., 2008). This is
the instance of the South American passive margin, which might have sectors behaving as a
typical passive margin that laterally coexist with sectors experiencing intense tectonism
(Matos 2000; Bird, 2001). The latter is attributed to reactivation of fracture zones and
transform faults, a process that might have continued during drifting (Greenroyd et al., 2008;
Basile et al., 2013). A consequence of such complex tectonic setting is the creation of new
space for sediment accumulation even in late stages of plate evolution (Yang and Escalona,
2011).
Taking the above into account, it is possible to postulate that the extensional and
compressional deformation recorded during the post?rift stage of the Paraíba Basin may be
linked to specific sectors of the South American passive margin with a dynamic evolution that
97
would have favored the reactivation of fracture zones. Indeed, the fact that this basin is
located in a complex structural setting that represents the youngest rifted segment of the
eastern Brazilian margin, and which records exceptionally very fast stretching in the order of
5 My (Matos, 1998), leads to consider the possibility that it may have experienced late
tectonism. Therefore, it is reasonable to postulate the reactivation of at least some sectors of
the southern Atlantic fracture zones, which would have propagated into the major shear zones
that intercept the Paraíba Basin, and caused deformation of its sedimentary units along the
geological time, even in the Late Pleistocene. An example of a major structural lineament
from other area of northeastern Brazil that was reactivated in the Late Pleistocene is the
Pirapemas Lineament (Almeida Filho et al., 2009). This feature was interpreted as a reflex of
reactivations along a major deep?seated basement strike?slip fault with dextral displacement
that are comparable in length and trend to the mega shear zones that underlie the Paraíba
Basin. The shear zone associated with the Pirapemas Lineament prolongs offshore into a
fracture zone that propagates into the Accra Fault in the western African continent (Almeida
Filho et al., 2009). This example serves to illustrate that the dynamic evolution of major
structures that cross the southern Atlantic Ocean includes reactivations in a relatively recent
geological time that includes the Late Pleistocene. Therefore, it is possible that such dynamic
behavior of fracture zones might have also propagated into intraplate areas of eastern South
America. This would have influenced the evolution of deep?based strike?slip shear zones
even up to the Late Pleistocene and, as a consequence, caused the pervasive extensional and
compressional deformation documented in the Paraíba Basin. However, further investigation
must be undertaken in this area to raise a larger data basis that can better demonstrate the
linkage between these deformation events with the southern Atlantic fracture zones in order to
better approach the post?rift evolution of the South American passive margin.
6.2.6 Conclusions
Although sea level fluctuations may have contributed to explain part of the erosional
and depositional episodes reconstructed in the onshore Paraíba Basin, it is unquestionable that
tectonic reactivation had the most significant contribution to define its sedimentary evolution.
The present approach integrating surface and subsurface geological information enabled to
characterize numerous tectonic structures in this basin. These include reverse, normal and
strike?slip faults, as well as folds, which altogether were related to extensional and
compressional deformation. The most likely is that such events result from multiple
98
reactivation phases of pre?existing E?W, NE?SW and NW?SE trending deep?based shear
zones. However, the possible contribution of an independent E?W extensional stress field
cannot be discarded. Successive stages of tectonic reactivation were responsible for
generating space to accommodate new sedimentation through time. Thicker sedimentary units
were formed overlying subsiding areas represented by grabens. Tectonic reactivation in this
area gave rise to basin establishment in the late Cretaceous, and such dynamics remained
active during the entire post?rift phase. Indeed, intense deformation of the Late Pleistocene
deposits in the Paraíba Basin attests the recurrence of extensional and compressional
deformation associated with the reactivation of strike?slip faults until a relatively recent
geological time. Therefore, the Paraíba Basin is regarded as an area of the South American
passive margin that remained tectonically active during most of its evolution, with significant
extensional and compressional focal deformation even in the Late Pleistocene. For this
reason, this basin, as well as its offshore extension, should continue being investigated in
order to collect additional data that may contribute to better discuss the post?rift history of
passive margins.

7 CONCLUSÕES
Esta tese de doutorado integrou informações geológicas de superfície e subsuperfície e
reconheceu diferentes estágios de deposição sedimentar na porção central emersa da Bacia
Paraíba.
Embora as flutuações do nível do mar possam ter contribuído para explicar parte dos
episódios de erosão e deposição reconstruídos na Bacia do Paraíba, é inquestionável que a
reativação tectônica teve a contribuição mais expressiva na sua evolução sedimentar. A
abordagem integradora deste trabalho permitiu a caracterização de inúmeras estruturas
tectônicas nesta bacia. Estas estruturas são rúpteis e dúcteis e incluem falhas normais,
inversas, transcorrentes, e dobras. Estas feições estão associadas a eventos deformacionais de
natureza extensional e compressional. O mais provável é que esses eventos resultam de
múltiplas fases de reativação de zonas de cisalhamento pré?existentes com orientação E?W,
NE?SW e NW?SE. No entanto, a possível contribuição de um campo de tensões extensional
independente E?W não pode ser descartada. Sucessivas fases de reativação tectônica foram
responsáveis pela geração de espaço para acomodar a sedimentação iniciada no final do
Cretáceo e se estenderam durante toda a fase pós?rifte. A intensa deformação dos depósitos
do Pleistoceno Superior na Bacia do Paraíba atesta a recorrência de deformação extensional e
compressional até um tempo geológico relativamente recente. Portanto, a Bacia do Paraíba
deve ser considerada uma área da margem passiva sul?americana que se manteve
tectonicamente ativa durante a maior parte de sua evolução.
Considerando a efetividade da metodologia de mapeamento criada para discriminação
de unidade neógenas e quaternárias comprovada neste trabalho, é importante destacar que as
unidades Pós?Barreiras tem uma representação espacial maior que as demais unidades
sedimentares na Bacia Paraíba e, possivelmente, esta expressiva ocorrência se estenda para
outras áreas da costa nordeste. Por essa razão, dados devem continuar sendo coletados em
outras bacias marginais do nordeste do Brasil de modo que a história pós?rifte de margens
passivas, em particular a sul?americana, possa ser melhor discutida.
